metadata.case_name: Prativa Bose v. Rupendra Deb Raikat

facts.text: Raja Prosanna Deb Raikat, proprietor of the Baikundiapur Raj Estate in Jalpaiguri, West Bengal, died intestate on December 4, 1946, leaving widow Rani Asrumati Debi (now deceased) and daughter Prativa Bose (appellant).
Rani Asrumati Debi took possession of the estate upon the Raja's death.

Respondent Rupendra, claiming to be the eldest son of the Raja by Rani Renchi (Lepcha tribe, married per Gandharba form), instituted suit on August 7, 1947, in Subordinate Judge's Court, Jalpaiguri, against Rani Asrumati and agnatic relations for declaration of sole heirship to the impartible estate governed by primogeniture, possession, and consequential reliefs.
Suit contested by Rani Asrumati and others denying marriage between Raja and Rani Renchi.
Suit transferred to Calcutta High Court on April 12, 1949, under cl. 13 Letters Patent, numbered Extraordinary Suit No. 2 of 1948.
Rupendra's application for receiver in High Court dismissed on July 29, 1952; appeal records do not show success.
Kumar Guru Charan and Kumar Jitendra filed suits in Calcutta High Court claiming title as sole heir; suits pending.
Rani Asrumati died on January 5, 1954; appellant Prativa Bose took possession claiming title.
Rupendra filed application on March 31, 1954, under s. 4 Bengal Regulation V of 1799 to District Judge, Jalpaiguri, for security from Prativa Bose.
District Judge dismissed application holding s.4 inapplicable to intestate death leaving single heir with disputes among claimants to be that heir, and barred by Art. 181 Limitation Act.
High Court in revision disagreed, set aside order, directed District Judge to take security from Prativa Bose; judgment dated June 6, 1956.
Estate is impartible governed by rule of primogeniture.

legal_issues.text: Whether s. 4 of Bengal Regulation V of 1799 applies to a case where deceased died intestate leaving a single heir, but right of succession disputed between several claimants each claiming to be the sole heir.
Whether respondent's application under s. 4 is barred by Art. 181 of Limitation Act.
Whether District Judge has jurisdiction to entertain application under s. 4 when suit pending in High Court.
Whether order demanding security under s. 4 is mandatory or discretionary.
Whether High Court could interfere in revision.

petitioner_arguments.text: Application barred under Art. 181 Limitation Act.
s. 4 applies only where more heirs than one; present case of single heir governed by s. 3 only, no security provision.
Jurisdiction lies only with court where suit pending (High Court), not District Judge.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal, Agra and Assam Civil Courts Act, 1887, s. 23

petitioner_arguments.text: Barred by principles analogous to res judicata due to High Court refusal of receiver.
Regulation impliedly repealed by Succession Act, 1925 ss. 192-195.
High Court no jurisdiction in revision as District Judge neither exceeded nor refused jurisdiction.

respondent_arguments.text: s. 4 applies where right of succession disputed between several claimants, including where each claims to be sole heir.
No limitation under Art. 181 as s. 4 contemplates no application, court acts suo motu.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Regulation V of 1799, s. 4; Limitation Act Art. 181

respondent_arguments.text: District Judge has jurisdiction under s. 4 independent of suit court.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v. Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb

court_reasoning.text: Art. 181 inapplicable as s. 4 requires no application, court acts suo motu; even if application needed, Art. 181 confined to CPC applications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regulation nowhere requires application; precedents support no limitation.

court_reasoning.text: District Judge (Zila Court successor) has jurisdiction under s. 4, not limited to suit court; Subordinate Judge only if authorized by High Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 4 judge is Zila Court judge i.e. District Judge.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J (separate opinion): s. 4 applies to disputes among claimants to single heirship; but security discretionary, not mandatory; remand to District Judge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words 'if the right of succession... disputed between several claimants' include single heir disputes; context shows discretion.

court_reasoning.text: Raghubar Dayal J (judgment): s. 4 does not apply to single heir cases (s. 3 governs); ss. 3 and 4 complete codes for distinct situations; no security for peaceful possession under s. 3.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regulation limits court interference; s. 4 for multiple heirs without agreement on manager; unreasonable to require security from sole heir claimant.

court_reasoning.text: No implied repeal by Succession Act; differences exist.
High Court justified in revision as District Judge refused jurisdiction erroneously.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Erroneous refusal of jurisdiction invites revision.

holdings.text: s. 4 of Bengal Regulation V of 1799 does not apply to intestate death leaving single heir with claimants disputing who is that sole heir; s. 3 governs.
Art. 181 Limitation Act inapplicable to s. 4 proceedings.
District Judge has jurisdiction under s. 4.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Oriental Bank Corporation v. J. A. Charriol
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 181 no operation where no application required.
Art. 181 no operation where no application required.

precedents_cited.case_name: She Mulchand & Co. Ltd. v. Jawahar Mills Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 181 confined to CPC applications post-1948 amendments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kumar Punyendra Narain Deb v. Kumar Bharabendra Narayan Deb
precedents_cited.relevance: District Judge can order security even if suit not before him.

precedents_cited.case_name: Joy Chand Lal Babu v. Kamalaksha Chaudhury
precedents_cited.relevance: Revision lies if court erroneously refuses jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava

precedents_cited.relevance: No rule limiting later clause by semicolon-separated prior clause.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Regulation V of 1799
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs court interference in intestate estates; s.4 for security in disputed successions among multiple heirs.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Inapplicable to s.4 Regulation as no application required or not under CPC.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act, 1925
statutes_cited.relevance: Does not impliedly repeal Regulation s.4; differences in procedure.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 181 limited to applications under CPC; procedure may apply but application not under CPC.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal, Agra and Assam Civil Courts Act, 1887
statutes_cited.relevance: District Judge succeeds Zila Court; Subordinate Judge needs High Court authorization.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; respondent's application under s.4 dismissed as s.4 inapplicable to single heir succession disputes. Respondents to pay appellant's costs throughout.
outcome.relief_granted: Dismissal of security application; costs to appellant.
outcome.costs: Respondents to pay costs of appellant throughout.

key_quotes.text: "If the right of succession to the estate be disputed between several claimants, one or more of whom may have taken possession, the judge... shall take good and sufficient security..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of s.4 triggering security in disputed successions.

key_quotes.text: "We are of opinion that the second part of s. IV does not apply to the case where the deceased dies intestate leaving only one heir entitled to succeed to the entire estate..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Majority holding on inapplicability of s.4.

key_quotes.text: "The Regulation, therefore, should be construed strictly as a piece of restrictive legislation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Approach to interpreting Regulation limiting court interference.
